citation.article-title: Pseudonocardia chloroethenivorans sp. nov., a chloroethene-degrading actinomycete
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Pseudonocardia chloroethenivorans sp. nov.
Pseudonocardia chloroethenivorans (chlor.o.e.the.ni.vor′ans. N.L. n. chloroethenum chloroethene; L. part. adj. vorans devouring; N.L. part. fem. adj. chloroethenivorans chloroethene-devouring).
Cells are Gram-positive and aerobic.
Vegetative and aerial hyphae are branched but not fragmented.
Spores are borne at the ends of hyphae and are not motile.
Vegetative mycelia are white.
Diffusible pigments not observed.
Cells use a variety of organic compounds.
Acid is produced from d(+)-glucose, l(−)-rhamnose, d(+)-xylose, d(−)-trehalose, cellobiose, d(−)-mannitol, maltose, d(+)-lactose, l(+)-arabinose and salicin.
l-Tyrosine, xanthine and hypoxanthine are degraded.
Adenine is not degraded.
Urea is not degraded.
Growth does not occur in the presence of 4 or 5 % (w/v) NaCl.
Capable of growing on phenol as a source of carbon and energy.
TCE, cis-DCE and VC are degraded.
Cell wall contains meso-diaminopimelic acid as the diamino acid.
Whole-cell hydrolysate contains galactose and arabinose.
Lacks mycolic acid.
Major menaquinone is MK-8(H4).
The fatty acid found in the largest amounts in whole-cell preparations is 16 : 0 iso.

The type strain, SL-1T (=ATCC BAA-742T=DSM 44698T), was isolated from an aerobic laboratory enrichment in the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Washington, Seattle, WA, USA.
